Kup:


"Count with that!! " Said Kup whose ran towards Tucson's quarters an=
d Set a good amount of Arrows in Tucson's crossbow, then he opened his con =
link and said "your weapon is ready... Lord Elder what's the safest place o=
f the Ark? if A battle starts here i want to place Elita in the safest poin=
t."





From: Sandy 
Sent: Friday, March 12, 2010 10:02 PM
To: nbwrpg@yaho=
ogroups.com 
Subject: Re: Back to the Ark


  
Tucson knew how to deal with=
 followers. If they were still in the area, a good sonic blast from his son=
ar system would surely mess up their telemetry and do a number on their own=
 gyroscopic systems. He comes to a short halt, tired of being stalked, he k=
icks up dust around short pivoting tires with a loud screech, and configure=
s his sonar attack to be harmless to Autobt and Maximal kind but NOT harmle=
ss to Predacons or Decepticons! 

" That's it, I am not going to play by th=
e rules ANY MORE! THEY WANT TROUBLE THEY GOT IT!"

He blasts the sonar atta=
ck at full pitch.

" Kup, if you pick up a sonar disturbance, don't worry, =
it's me. It may effect your computer systems and I do appologize for that. =
But whatever or whoever is out there isn't about to get away that easy!" 

=
He puts himself into drive and continues his drive toward the Ark, blasting=
 the attack continuously.

"They think I'm a pushover on wheels, they'll th=
ink twice after this, I assure you Lord Elder... They'll think twice."

He =
tries really hard to hold back a short temper. Tucson knew when to play gam=
es and when it was time to get serious. This was the time to get serious.

=
"Oh yeah, Kup, in my quarters you'll find a cross bow in my weapon chamber.=
 Please, have that ready for me when I get back and make sure to put a good=
 amount of plasma arrows in the energizer for me. You'll find all of that n=
ear an old sun dial I was working on before I left the Ark ages ago."

He t=
urns his attentions back to Lord Elder.

" Before all this happened to me, =
my spare time was spent restorring old artifacts and weapons. I'm hoping to=
 go back to doing some resteration, it's the only thing that quells my temp=
er which I do admit, gets rather short in times like these. Remind me to sh=
ow you what I've done when we get back to the Ark. I have a small work area=
 in my quarters where I've managed to restore a few small artifacts... Well=
 including one fairly large sun dial.. But most of all, I've saved and rest=
orred ancient Autobot weaponry which may still prove useful to us now. I ha=
ve a feeling we might just need it."

--- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, Presto=
n Carroll <supercyclonus@...> wrote:
>
> The trip back is mildly uneventful=
. The day moved forward as the sun
> slid from its mid point position to a =
one significantly lower in the
> skies. Occasionally in the distance a larg=
e dinosaur could be seen,
> from a predator who glanced in the direction of=
 Lord Elder and Tuscon,
> but who realized quickly that this metal machine =
was definitely not
> prey; to a sauropod, who's small head on a long neck t=
urned to look
> at the vehicle passed by, and even the smaller variety of c=
reatures,
> from scavengers to predator, ones who typically scattered as th=
e
> vehicle that was Tuscon bounced and yet moved easily across the broken
=
> terrain.
> 
> Up ahead the trees, which had been near constant companions=
 during
> most of their trip began to break away as they came into more ope=
n
> country. Up ahead the beginnings of a mountain range could be seen.
> A=
bove them a flock of what could almost look like birds flew, although
> ins=
tead of possessing feathers, they had large leathery and larger
> bodies.
>=
 
> "We're almost back" Lord Elder said. He had been silent through most
> =
of the trip, his face wearing a thoughtful look. "There, that mountain
> ov=
er there, at the base of it."
> 
> "I'll activate the door in the shield fo=
r us." Elder said as he was
> about to open a communication signal to the A=
rk. However Elder paused
> and look around, as if looking for something. "S=
omething's wrong here
> . . . " he said as he continued to look.
> 
> Above=
 them the prehistoric avians turned almost as one, their calls
> almost def=
iant as they moved swiftly in the direction that Tuscon and
> Elder had com=
e from. "It's like we're being watched."
> 
> (TAG)
> 
> Preston
> (Lord El=
der)
>
